rationale: ATLAS presents a clear and implementable architecture for sequential prompt adaptation in agentic trading workflows, and results are directionally strong in difficult bearish/volatile conditions. However, narrow evaluation scope, deterministic execution assumptions, low run count, and non-universal superiority across all model/regime cells make immediate autonomous production deployment unjustified.
rejection_reasons: Reject immediate autonomous live-trading deployment due to simulator realism gaps (slippage, latency, partial fills, intraday microstructure not modeled).
Reject broad production claims until robustness is shown beyond three assets and one two-month window.
Reject confidence in universal superiority because some model/regime cells do not outperform static baselines.
Reject high-confidence rollout without higher-powered repeated-run statistics and significance analysis.
recommendations: Implement Adaptive-OPRO as a controlled R&D capability with strict template-preservation checks.
Use order-level auditable outputs and keep reflection guidance optional plus gated.
Expand experiments to multi-year walk-forward evaluation over broader universes.
Add realistic transaction-cost and execution-friction models before promotion decisions.
Increase repeats and publish uncertainty/significance bands for key metrics.
follow_up_actions: Run ablations over Adaptive-OPRO internals (window length, score mapping, optimizer backbone, template constraints) to identify causal gain drivers.
Validate regime-generalization on additional sectors and lower-liquidity assets.
Benchmark against stronger modern non-LLM baselines under identical execution assumptions.
Define promotion gates: minimum risk-adjusted uplift thresholds, max drawdown limits, and statistical confidence requirements.
